text: To my knowledge Java is still a very commonly used server-side language. Python became embedded into Linux a long time ago in multiple subsystems; various build systems like yum which is the essential tool used in Centos/RedHat, and so on. In fact Centos 6.5 and earlier requires Python 2.6 else you can't run the OS, and for some reason if you install python 3 which has breaking changes to 2.6, Centos malfunctions. Most linux distributions are collections of hundreds of different utilities, and each of those has a dependency chain. The poor design of the Unix shared library (DLL's to those familiar with Windows) has been its achilles heel for a long time. This is why linux doesn't make much forward progress; most of the builds are just reshufflings of the existing tools rather than forward motion, held back by the inability to gracefully move forward. The whole Docker ecosystem can be considered to exist solely to fix the shared library conflict issue, by creating a custom environment for each program to exist in. A terrible band-aid over a festering sore IMHO.

The poor design of the Unix shared library (DLL's to those familiar with Windows) has been its achilles heel for a long time. This is why linux doesn't make much forward progress; most of the builds are just reshufflings of the existing tools rather than forward motion, held back by the inability to gracefully move forward. The whole Docker ecosystem can be considered to exist solely to fix the shared library conflict issue, by creating a custom environment for each program to exist in. A terrible band-aid over a festering sore IMHO.

text:
<@UCUSW7WVD> thanks! Couple of things to unpack. Firstly, <http://s-ol.nu|s-ol.nu> (the root domain) is a permalink redirector as you guessed: <http://s-ol.nu/why-redirectly|s-ol.nu/why-redirectly> I use it mainly when sharing links on social media, or in this case because the thesis is going to be printed and I want to be sure the links mentioned in the text body stay working for a long time.

As for <https://ba.s-ol.nu|https://ba.s-ol.nu>: that subdomain was set up to track the ba branch of the git repo, where I did all the changes that are part of the thesis. My main website is at <https://mmm.s-ol.nu|https://mmm.s-ol.nu>, and a bit more stable. <http://ba.s-ol.nu|ba.s-ol.nu> is going to stay up at least until my thesis evaluation is over, just to be sure, but then it will probably go away, with the changes merged into master and the permalink updated accordingly.

text:
The other two questions are part of mmmfs itself:
the loading behavior is very bad (or sad) due to a combination of issues that I would have liked to address during the working time but ended up not having time to. It goes something like this:
- the server and client share most of the mmmfs code and abilities, but there are some differences: only the server can compile MoonScript to Lua, and the two Markdown implementations (sadly) have minor differences. Only the client can use some JS libraries (mermaid.js, svg.js)
- the server pre-renders a static version of the page when a page is requested
- the client re-renders the page after initializing the runtime and fetching the sources. This is often necessary because of the differences above, but it currently happens in any case, because I don't know which pages need or don't need this to happen.
- fetching resources and is currently happening completely synchronously, and rendering is running in <http://fengari.io|fengari.io>, both of which makes everything pretty slow. Also conversions aren't cached, and some conversions involve HTTP request.
- the flash to white while the client rerenders happens a bit to early, because of the non-async implementation of that part.

So yeah, lots to improve there. You can check the server-side version my removing the `+interactive` from the URL end; in the case of the thesis the markdown difference ends up formatting the sidenotes in a particularly ugly fashion as you will see.

- fetching resources and is currently happening completely synchronously, and rendering is running in

- the flash to white while the client rerenders happens a bit to early, because of the non-async implementation of that part.

So yeah, lots to improve there. You can check the server-side version my removing the
from the URL end; in the case of the thesis the markdown difference ends up formatting the sidenotes in a particularly ugly fashion as you will see.

text: As for the facet dropdown, facets are the typed (and named) attributes of fileders storing all content in mmmfs. Sometimes they are used rather as different attributes (such as a human-friendly title for a folder), sometimes they are used as alternative variants of the same content (gallery and slideshow view of a list of pictures). For the thesis, there are two variants; one which only links to the project log and one which embeds all pages (for printing).

elements.text: As for the facet dropdown, facets are the typed (and named) attributes of fileders storing all content in mmmfs. Sometimes they are used rather as different attributes (such as a human-friendly title for a folder), sometimes they are used as alternative variants of the same content (gallery and slideshow view of a list of pictures). For the thesis, there are two variants; one which only links to the project log and one which embeds all pages (for printing).

text: In the Inspector, you can view the contents of all facets of the current fileder, and see the list of child fileders. On <https://sandbox.s-ol.nu|https://sandbox.s-ol.nu> you can also edit both.

text: <@UMVFWPZ36> It seems to me that it should move towards something closer to how we program, which is with graphs whose nodes are objects of various types (numbers, strings, arrays, sets… even tensors).

text: hey <@UA14TGLTC> if you want to explore more wacky lisps especially on the topic of dynamic scoping, you should check out <http://www.newlisp.org/|http://www.newlisp.org/> and <https://picolisp.com/wiki/?home|https://picolisp.com/wiki/?home> , two very weird, small, surprisingly feature-complete lisps that i wish had more eyeballs on them

attachments.title: newLISP  - Home
attachments.text: newLISP is a general purpose scripting language for developing web applications and programs in general in the domains of artificial intelligence (AI), statistics and machine learning.

attachments.title: Loom | Video recording, simplified.
attachments.text: Get your message across with instantly shareable videos for work. Capture your screen, record your front-facing camera, and narrate it all at once, then instantly share with a simple link.
